full_title_en: IMPACT Score for Outcomes in Head Injury
medium_description_en: Predicts 6-month mortality and unfavorable outcomes after moderate to severe traumatic brain injury (TBI).
instructions_en: Use for patients ≥14 years old with GCS ≤12 (moderate and severe TBI). Use data from the first 24 hours of admission.

seo.meta_description_en: The IMPACT Score for Outcomes in Head Injury predicts 6-month mortality and unfavorable outcomes after moderate to severe traumatic brain injury (TBI).
seo.keywords_en: Impact score, impact calculator, tbi, traumatic brain injury

how_to_use.use_case_en: Patients ≥14 years old admitted to critical care units with GCS ≤12 (moderate and severe TBI).
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• Developed to provide early prognostication; therefore, data from the first 24 hours of admission should be used.
  • Should NOT be used for serial evaluations or updating prognosis with progression of care.
  • Original datasets were developed in high-income countries and therefore may not be applicable in developing countries or areas with otherwise limited medical resources. 
  • Best used for isolated head injuries, as other comorbidities and extracranial injuries are not taken into consideration in this score and may contribute to patient mortality.
how_to_use.why_use_en: Prognostic models aim to provide a spectrum of probable outcomes in patients based on populations of patients. This tool provides useful information that may help clinicians and surrogate decisionmakers to determine the goals of treatment and care relative to the possibilities of outcomes.

next_steps.critical_actions_en: Outcomes are meant to describe prognosis on the population level.  It should NOT be used as alone for clinical decisionmaking in individual patients such as withholding aggressive therapies.

about.formula_en:
Probability of 6-month mortality or unfavorable outcome = 1 / (1 + e-x), where x is as follows:


Model 

6-month outcome

Mortality

Unfavorable outcome*

Core

x = -3.109 + addition of the selected points**

x = -2.644 + addition of the selected points

Extended

x = -3.787 + addition of the selected points

x = -3.023 + addition of the selected points

Lab

x = -3.184 + addition of the selected points

x = -2.470 + addition of the selected points

*Unfavorable outcome = death, persistent vegetative state, or severe disability.

**Points for each variable in the core, extended, and lab models are provided below.

*Marshall CT classification:

Classification

Definition

Diffuse injury I

No visible intracranial pathology

Diffuse injury II

Cisterns present, midline shift ≤5 mm and/or lesion densities, no high/mixed density lesion >25 cm³

Diffuse injury III

Cisterns compressed or absent, midline shift ≤5 mm, no high/mixed density lesion >25 cm³

Diffuse injury IV

Midline shift >5 mm, no high/mixed density lesion >25 cm³

V

Any surgically-evacuated lesion

VI

High/mixed density lesion >25 cm³, not surgically evacuated
about.evidence_based_medicine_en:
The International Mission for Prognosis and Analysis of Clinical Trials in TBI (IMPACT) project was a collaborative effort to standardize research practices in the study of TBI. The IMPACT database, consisting of patient data from eight randomized controlled trials and three observational studies between 1984 and 1997, is the source from which the models presented here were developed (Steyerberg 2008).

Using 8,509 patients age 14 and up with moderate to severe TBI, the IMPACT investigators developed three models based on variables previously described to have prognostic value (Murray 2007). Each subsequent model builds on the previous to add additional clinical data when available.

Primary outcomes for prediction were 6-month mortality and 6-month outcomes dichotomized as favorable (Glasgow Outcome Score (GOS) 4-5) and unfavorable (GOS 1-3).

The models were internally validated using data sets within the IMPACT database, then externally validated with patients from the Medical Research Council Corticosteroid Randomization of Significant Head Injury (MRC CRASH) trial, which included 6,681 eligible patients.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Steyerberg EW, Mushkudiani N, Perel P, et al. Predicting outcome after traumatic brain injury: development and international validation of prognostic scores based on admission characteristics. PLoS Med. 2008;5(8):e165.

Other References.text: Murray GD, Butcher I, Mchugh GS, et al. Multivariable prognostic analysis in traumatic brain injury: results from the IMPACT study. J Neurotrauma. 2007;24(2):329-37.

Validation.text: Roozenbeek B, Lingsma HF, Lecky FE, et al. Prediction of outcome after moderate and severe traumatic brain injury: external validation of the International Mission on Prognosis and Analysis of Clinical Trials (IMPACT) and Corticoid Randomisation After Significant Head injury (CRASH) prognostic models. Crit Care Med. 2012;40(5):1609-17.

Harrison DA, Griggs KA, Prabhu G, et al. External Validation and Recalibration of Risk Prediction Models for Acute Traumatic Brain Injury among Critically Ill Adult Patients in the United Kingdom. J Neurotrauma. 2015;32(19):1522-37.

Sun H, Lingsma HF, Steyerberg EW, Maas AI. External Validation of the International Mission for Prognosis and Analysis of Clinical Trials in Traumatic Brain Injury: Prognostic Models for Traumatic Brain Injury on the Study of the Neuroprotective Activity of Progesterone in Severe Traumatic Brain Injuries Trial. J Neurotrauma. 2016;33(16):1535-43.

creator_info.about_en: Ewout W. Steyerberg, PhD, is a professor at Leiden University Medical Center and Erasmus Medical Center in the Netherlands. He is also the head of the department of medical statistics and bioinformatics. Dr. Steyerberg’s research focuses primarily on biostatistics, clinical epidemiology, and medical decision making.

input_schema.tips_en: Each subsequent model builds on the previous to add additional clinical data when available

input_schema.tips_en: If on sedation/paralysis or unable to be assessed, mark as "Not testable (NT)"

V or VI (evacuated or non-evacuated mass lesion)
